articles.headline: Clinton Aides Split on How to Take On Obama
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton has been stymied by the challenge of how to discredit her popular opponent without hurting herself.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton has been stymied by the challenge of how to discredit her popular opponent without hurting herself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton meets Senator Barack Obama at a one-on-one debate in Austin on Thursday night, one of her final opportunities to change the course of the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, she will again face the challenge that has repeatedly stymied her: how to discredit her popular opponent without hurting herself.

articles.headline: For McCain, Self-Confidence on Ethics Poses Its Own Risk
articles.snippet: As his relationship with a female lobbyist underscores, John McCain’s confidence in his own integrity sometimes seems to blind him to potential conflicts.
articles.abstract: As his relationship with a female lobbyist underscores, John McCain’s confidence in his own integrity sometimes seems to blind him to potential conflicts.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Marilyn W. Thompson, David D. Kirkpatrick and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: Top Court Allows Suit Over 401(k)
articles.snippet: The ruling gives retirement plan participants the right to sue to recover losses when their investment instructions are ignored or the account is otherwise mishandled.
articles.abstract: The ruling gives retirement plan participants the right to sue to recover losses when their investment instructions are ignored or the account is otherwise mishandled.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Participants in 401(k) retirement plans can sue to recover losses when their investment instructions are ignored or the account is otherwise mishandled, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

articles.headline: French Bank Says Its Controls Failed for 2 Years
articles.snippet: An investigation has found that Jérôme Kerviel began making unauthorized bets in 2005 that Société Générale’s internal controls failed to uncover.
articles.abstract: An investigation has found that Jérôme Kerviel began making unauthorized bets in 2005 that Société Générale’s internal controls failed to uncover.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  A rogue trader at Société Générale, Jérôme Kerviel, began making unauthorized transactions beginning in 2005, and lapses in the bank’s internal controls allowed the trades to go undiscovered until January, according to a preliminary report released Wednesday.

articles.headline: Rising Inflation Limits the Fed as Growth Lags
articles.snippet: The United States has not faced stagflation, the mix of slumping growth and oil and food price spikes, in decades.
articles.abstract: The United States has not faced stagflation, the mix of slumping growth and oil and food price spikes, in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, for all its power, faces tough new limits on its ability to keep the economy out of a recession.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Web Movies Show Why DVDs Sell
articles.snippet: The Internet movie download era may be more distant than you think.
articles.abstract: The Internet movie download era may be more distant than you think.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ten days ago, Netflix announced that it would abandon HD DVD, Toshiba's entry in the high-definition DVD format war. Six days ago, Wal-Mart dropped HD DVD, too. Then two days ago, Toshiba surrendered, marking the end of the most pointless format war since Betamax-VHS.

articles.headline: That ’70s Look: Stagflation
articles.snippet: Will an economic slowdown counter a rise in prices? That’s the Fed’s view.
articles.abstract: Will an economic slowdown counter a rise in prices? That’s the Fed’s view.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lately, many people are hearing an echo  faintly perhaps but distinctly audible  of the stagflation of the 1970s.

articles.headline: Justices Shield Medical Devices From Lawsuits
articles.snippet: Makers of medical devices like implantable defibrillators are immune from liability for personal injuries as long as the F.D.A. approved the device before it was marketed.
articles.abstract: Makers of medical devices like implantable defibrillators are immune from liability for personal injuries as long as the F.D.A. approved the device before it was marketed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Makers of medical devices like implantable defibrillators or breast implants are immune from liability for personal injuries as long as the Food and Drug Administration approved the device before it was marketed and it meets the agency’s specifications, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

articles.headline: U.S. Security Concerns Block China’s 3Com Deal
articles.snippet: A $2.2 billion offer for the network equipment maker 3Com stalled amid fears that equipment made for the U.S. military might be sabotaged.
articles.abstract: A $2.2 billion offer for the network equipment maker 3Com stalled amid fears that equipment made for the U.S. military might be sabotaged.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Does the “America for Sale” sign require a warning label?

articles.headline: Race Matters Less in Politics of South
articles.snippet: The election of black candidates in mostly white districts suggests that black politicians can win in unlikely places.
articles.abstract: The election of black candidates in mostly white districts suggests that black politicians can win in unlikely places.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULLMAN, Ala.  The racial breakthroughs have come gingerly in Alabama over the years: a black mayor there, an old Klansman put on trial here, a civil rights memorial there.
